body:
This page includes several video tutorials to help you get started in your new Canvas course. 

What is Canvas you ask?  Well, Canvas is a cloud-based learning management system (LMS) developed by Instructure, Inc. The University of Cincinnati has chosen to pursue a pilot of this LMS based on the benefits and enhanced learning experiences shown in other local institutions which have chosen to migrate to the Canvas platform from another LMS, such as Blackboard.

FAQs 

Where's Blackboard?

After extensive testing and a semester long pilot, UC has decided to adopt Canvas by Instructure to be the learning management system for the university.  Beginning in Summer of 2019 and continuing through Spring of 2020, you will see more and more of your courses in Canvas instead of Blackboard. Please check with your instructor to be sure which system you should access for each course.

Why is UC moving to Canvas?

Canvas is generally thought to be easier to use for both faculty and students.  We hope you'll agree, because we care about your learning experience.  Student feedback during the pilot was very positive and was a driving factor in the decision to switch to Canvas.

Will all my courses be in Canvas?

Probably not at first, but by Summer of 2020, yes, all your courses will be on Canvas.  In the meantime, we realize that means that you might have to access both Canvas and Blackboard to get to the material for all your courses.  We know that's a pain, but it's just not possible to move the entire university to a new learning management system all at once. We appreciate your patience during the transition.

What if I have an Incomplete or an ongoing research project during the last semester we have Blackboard? Will I be able to finish my course work?

Yes.  Your instructors will be able to move their courses from Blackboard to Canvas so you can finish your course work. 

I belong to an organization that uses a Blackboard course site to communicate and share files.  What happens to that?

Those details are still being worked out, but organizations that have a Blackboard course site will be provided a space to continue to share their files and to communicate with each other.  Stay tuned for details about that during the 2019-2020 school year.

Where do I find help if I need it?

We're really hoping that Canvas is so much easier to use that you won't run into much trouble.  But if you do, contact the 24/7 Help Line at 1-(855)-745-4414.  Also, you can access the handy tutorials on using Canvas above on this page.

Clermont Student Services and Academic Support

UC Clermont: Academic Advising

We are committed to providing advice and assistance throughout your academic journey. Your advisor works with you to create an academic plan based on your goals.

UC Clermont: Academic Success Center

The Academic Success Center offers free tutoring for all UC Clermont College students. Located in Peters-Jones 104, the ASC is a great place for students to find assistance in a variety of subject areas. Our friendly, professional staff will work with students one-on-one or in groups.

Academic Success Center Hours:

Monday – Thursday 8 a.m. – 6:30 p.m.

Friday 8 a.m. – 4 p.m.

Walk in to set up an appointment, call us at 513.732.5339 or email us at Clermont.tutoring@uc.edu.

UC Clermont: Academics & Educational Services

UC Clermont Academics: Academic Departments, General Academic Information, Majors & Programs and Educational Services.

UC Clermont: Experiential Learning and Career Education

We are all things career -  internships, resumes, interviews and jobs and more. We work with you one-on-one to navigate the career process no matter the need.

UC Clermont: OneStop

OneStop Center is located on the UC Clermont College campus, in the Student Services Building, Room 100.  We are available daily during regular business hours for matters related to your registration, financial aid and your bill.  OneStop resources are also available 24/7 online.

UC Clermont: Student Services Support

Please review UC Clermont’s Additional Student Resources such as: UC Clermont Bookstore, UC Clermont Public Safety, Campus Life and Emergency Text Messaging.

UC Clermont Counseling Services

The Compass Counseling Center provides students assistance in helping to deal with life’s stressors and adjustment to college life. All services provided to UC Clermont students are free and confidential. Some of the most common issues addressed at the center include transition to college life, stress from home, classroom performance, depression, anxiety, relationship problems, grief and loss, and substance abuse. Students are welcome and encouraged to walk into the Compass Counseling Center located in the Student. Services Building, Room 201. Students may contact the office by calling (513) 732-5263. If after hours, please call CAPS Cares (main campus) using the 24 Hour Phone Consultation Line at 513-556-0648.

Title IX

Title IX is a federal civil rights law that prohibits discrimination on the basis of your actual or perceived sex, gender, gender identity, gender expression, or sexual orientation. Title IX also covers sexual violence, dating or domestic violence, and stalking. If you disclose a Title IX issue to me, I am required forward that information to the Title IX Office. They will follow up with you about how the University can take steps to address the impact on you and the community and make you aware of your rights and resources. Their priority is to make sure you are safe and successful here. You are not required to talk with the Title IX Office. If you would like to make a report of sex or gender-based discrimination, harassment or violence, or if you would like to know more about your rights and resources on campus, you can consult the website www.uc.edu/titleix or contact the office at 556-3349.

The University of Cincinnati is committed to creating an inclusive and equitable academic environment. If you have a disability (e.g., visual impairment, hearing impairment, physical impairment, communication disorder, and/or specific learning disability, etc.) which may influence your performance in this course, you must meet with the Accessibility Resource (AR) to arrange for reasonable accommodations to ensure an equitable opportunity to meet all the requirements of this course. If you require accommodations due to disability, please contact AR at 513-556-6823, Campus Location: 210 University Pavilion or email them at disabisv@ucmail.uc.edu You will be provided an Accommodation Form indicating your accommodation needs for the semester. Please present this form to your instructor as soon as possible to ensure your accommodation needs are discussed, agreed upon, and provided.

If you are a student veteran and believe that a service connected conditions, such as traumatic brain injury (TBI) post- traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), may impact your academic success, please contact UC’s Veterans Services office. The University, in collaboration with the Cincinnati VA Medical Center, has created the Veterans Integration to Academic Leadership (VITAL). This program provides student veterans with academic assistance, advocacy and access to healthcare. Learn more about VITAL and the service offerings.

UC Libraries Adaptive Technology Lab (link)

The handicap accessible Adaptive Technologies Lab, located in Langsam Library, offers an array of services to students, including large format monitors, screen reading, dictation and magnification software. The lab is available 24 hours a day on a first come, first serve basis, however, priority will be given to students with accommodations.

Clermont Technology Support Desk

Located in CCSNYDER Room S141

Anyone seeking technical assistance may stop by room S141 in the Snyder building to the Center for Instructional Design and Technology Support.  Support is available anytime during posted office hours for a face-to-face conversation with a member of our support team. No appointment is necessary. The Technology Services team staffs the Technology Support Desk which is setup within the IDTS Center. After 4:30pm the Technology Support Desk is staffed by student assistants. To simplify the process of addressing your support needs, we encourage you to contact the Technology support Desk @732-5216 (45216 internally), or via email at Clermont.Support@uc.edu.

This support includes email, Canopy tools (Box at UC, Echo360, Kaltura, WebEx), wireless access, VPN, UC Flex, file servers and the mainframe.

  • Questions? - Please search our 24/7 Knowledge Base for troubleshooting and support documentation
  • Problems? - Click here to submit a support ticket

Counseling Services, Clifton Campus

Students have access to counseling and mental health care through the University Health Services (UHS), which can provide both psychotherapy and psychiatric services. In addition, Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS) can provide professional counseling upon request; students may receive five free counseling sessions through CAPS without insurance. Students are encouraged to seek assistance for anxiety, depression, trauma/assault, adjustment to college life, interpersonal/relational difficulty, sexuality, family conflict, grief and loss, disordered eating and body image, alcohol and substance abuse, anger management, identity development and issues related to diversity, concerns associated with sexual orientation and spirituality concerns, as well as any other issue of concerns. After hours, students may call UHS at 513-556-2564 or CAPS Cares at 513-556-0648. For urgent physician consultation after-hours students may call 513-584-7777. For more information, visit Counseling and Psychological Services.

Counseling Services, Blue Ash Campus

UC Blue Ash Counseling Services provides high quality integrated health, counseling, and wellness services. Mental Health and personal counseling services are free of charge to students who are matriculated as UC Blue Ash College students. Services address student needs such as self esteem, family conflict, loss and grief issues, adjusting to life’s challenges, relationship problems, eating disorders, physical and/or emotional abuse, and domestic violence. Students who want an initial meeting with a counselor can call (513) 745-5670 or stop by Room 140 Muntz Hall to schedule an appointment. If after hours, please call CAPS Cares (main campus) using the 24 Hour Phone Consultation Line at 513-556-0648. For more information, visit Counseling and Psychological Services.

Counseling Services, Clermont Campus

The Compass Counseling Center provides students assistance in helping to deal with life’s stressors and adjustment to college life. All services provided to UC Clermont students are free and confidential. Some of the most common issues addressed at the center include transition to college life, stress from home, classroom performance, depression, anxiety, relationship problems, grief and loss, and substance abuse. Students are welcome and encouraged to walk into the Compass Counseling Center located in the Student. Services Building, Room 201. Students may contact the office by calling (513) 732-5263. If after hours, please call CAPS Cares (main campus) using the 24 Hour Phone Consultation Line at 513-556-0648. For more information, visit Counseling and Psychological Services. 

Title IX

Title IX is a federal civil rights law that prohibits discrimination on the basis of your actual or perceived sex, gender, gender identity, gender expression, or sexual orientation. Title IX also covers sexual violence, dating or domestic violence, and stalking. If you disclose a Title IX issue to me, I am required forward that information to the Title IX Office. They will follow up with you about how the University can take steps to address the impact on you and the community and make you aware of your rights and resources. Their priority is to make sure you are safe and successful here. You are not required to talk with the Title IX Office. If you would like to make a report of sex or gender-based discrimination, harassment or violence, or if you would like to know more about your rights and resources on campus, you can consult the website www.uc.edu/titleix or contact the office at 556-3349.

FAQs 

Where's Blackboard?

After extensive testing and a semester long pilot, UC has decided to adopt Canvas by Instructure to be the learning management system for the university.  Beginning in Summer of 2019 and continuing through Spring of 2020, you will see more and more of your courses in Canvas instead of Blackboard. Please check with your instructor to be sure which system you should access for each course.

Why is UC moving to Canvas?

Canvas is generally thought to be easier to use for both faculty and students.  We hope you'll agree, because we care about your learning experience.  Student feedback during the pilot was very positive and was a driving factor in the decision to switch to Canvas.

Will all my courses be in Canvas?

Probably not at first, but by Summer of 2020, yes, all your courses will be on Canvas.  In the meantime, we realize that means that you might have to access both Canvas and Blackboard to get to the material for all your courses.  We know that's a pain, but it's just not possible to move the entire university to a new learning management system all at once. We appreciate your patience during the transition.

What if I have an Incomplete or an ongoing research project during the last semester we have Blackboard? Will I be able to finish my course work?

Yes.  Your instructors will be able to move their courses from Blackboard to Canvas so you can finish your course work. 

I belong to an organization that uses a Blackboard course site to communicate and share files.  What happens to that?

Those details are still being worked out, but organizations that have a Blackboard course site will be provided a space to continue to share their files and to communicate with each other.  Stay tuned for details about that during the 2019-2020 school year.

Where do I find help if I need it?

We're really hoping that Canvas is so much easier to use that you won't run into much trouble.  But if you do, contact the 24/7 Help Line at 1-(855)-745-4414.  Also, you can access the handy tutorials on using Canvas above on this page.

body:

Overview

Module 1 will span the first two weeks of the course. This module will introduce basic notions of descriptive statistics and probability.  We will cover Chapters 1 and 2 of the Devore text.

We have two distinct goals in this chapter. Our first goal is to describe sets of data.  There are many different ways to do this- some methods are pictorial (such as graphs) and other ways are numerical.  Common numerical descriptions of data include describing a notion of the "center" and a measure of "dispersion" around the center.  Measures of center include mean, median, and mode. Measures of variance (or dispersion) include variance, standard deviation, and range.  We will also set some fundamental terminology such as "sample", "population", and other terms we will be using.

Our second goal is to outline the basics of probability theory.  Probability is the bedrock on which statistics lies.  Often times, probability is a challenging topic because there is a plethora of new terminology and techniques which may be unfamiliar.  We will introduce sample spaces and events which module the outcomes of random experiments. Then we will discuss counting techniques in order to introduce the mechanics of computing probability.  Finally, we will discuss the important concepts of independent and dependence and apply it to conditional probability.

Learning Objectives

  • Define probability
  • Define and compute marginal probabilities
  • Define and calculate joint probabilities
  • Define and compute conditional probabilities
  • Categorize  events as independent or not independent

Instructions

Please read and take notes over sections 1.1-1.4 in the textbook over Chapter One: Overview and Descriptive Statistics. 

If you take advantage of the e-textbook in WebAssign (WA), you'll find videos covering content and explaining examples. There may occasionally be notes illuminating particular passages.

The exercises section will have a variety of problems with which you can hone your skills in these new topics if you want practice outside of the homework assigned in WA. What may be most valuable for you in this area of the text are the exercises that have solutions worked out for you. If you find yourself in need of additional examples, this is where you might go first.

Instructions

Please read and take notes over the material in sections 2.1-2.5 on probability.

Take advantage of the e-textbook and the additional material there provided.

As always, I would recommend working example problems along with the text, justifying each step taken, and understanding the process undergone in each example before moving on. Videos are available for many examples, and most steps taken are small enough to be understood. If understanding is still elusive, please reach out to me (your instructor), or to the resources laid out in the "Student Support Service" page in the Getting Started module.

Overview

This module will introduce the concept of a random variables. Random variables are the foundation of probability theory and essentially the rest of the course will study random variables and their properties. This week will study sections 3.1-3.3, 4.1-4.2, and 5.1-5.2 of the course text.

Recall that during Module 1 we introduced the notion of a sample space as the set of all possible outcomes of a random experiment. A random variables can be succinctly described as a function on the sample space. We call the variable "random" because the numerical value that the variable takes depends on the random outcome of the experiment. Here is an example: Suppose our experiment consists of flipping a coin 5 times. Then the sample spaces consists of the 2^5 possible outcomes consisting of a list of 5 H's or T's (like HHHHH, HHHHT, HHHTH ,...). If X =the number of heads in the outcome, then we have defined a function on the sample space and this function takes the values 0, 1,2,3,4, or 5.

Random variables come in two distinct flavors: discrete and continuous. Discrete random variables are like the previous example- the number of values that the variable takes is only finite or listable. A continuous random variable takes an unlistable, infinite number of values in some interval (a, b). Understanding the distinction between these two classes of variables is an important goal this week. The distinct is crucial because the mathematical treatment of each type is different.

After we have defined random variables we will associate natural numerical measurements to them called expectation and variance. These will involve some calculus skills when we deal with continuous random variables. We will also introduce the appropriate generalizations if we have two or more random variables.

Learning Outcomes

  • Define a Random Variable
  • Define Discrete and Continuous Probability Distributions
  • Define Joint Probability Distributions
  • Calculate the Expected Value of a Random Variable
  • Compute the Variance and Covariance of a Random Variable

Overview

Now that we have basic concepts of random variables (both discrete random variables and continuous random variables), the notion of probability distributions, and the calculations of expected value and variance we will make an in depth study of some of the most common and most important distributions. The following are the distributions that we will study this week:

Discrete probability distributions: binomial distribution, hypergeometric distribution, negative binomial distribution, Poisson distribution (Sections 3.4-3.6)

Continuous probability distributions: normal distribution, exponential distribution, gamma distribution, chi-squared distribution (Sections 4.3-4.5).

There are several key take-away that you should aim for this week. Each of these types of distributions have what are called "parameters" that describe them (this is the same sense of the word that we learned in Module 01). For example, a normal distribution with mean 10 and standard deviation 5. You should work through the calculations of the expected value and variance for each type of distribution, but note that in each case they can be given simply in terms of the parameters. That means once you have verified the calculation once, you can just use the formulas. A second key take-away should be applications. Investigate when you might want to use the different types of distributions. We must keep in mind math is a tool- we are learning how to use hammers, screw drivers, saws, etc. We don't first learn to use our tools on the final project, though. It is easy to be short sighted and thing that we are just doing math for math's sake, but in reality we need to keep an eye out for physical applications of these ideas.

Learning Outcomes

  • Define the Binomial, Multinomial and Hypergeometric Distributions
  • Define the Negative Binomial and Geometric Distribution
  • Examine the Poisson and Uniform Distributions
  • Examine the Normal Distribution
  • Analyze areas under the normal distribution
  • Define the Gamma and Exponential Distribution
  • Analyze the Chi-Squared Distribution

Overview

In Module 4 we will study statistics, the distributions of statistics, and point estimation. This module covers sections 5.3-5.5 and 6.1-6.2 of course text.

Recall statistics are numbers that are based on a single sample and as such we may consider something like "sample mean" as a random variable it it's own right. As a random variable, it will itself have a distribution. We will introduce some statistics we have mentioned before and then study what they distributions are. In chapter 6 we will introduce point estimation. Recall that one of our goals in inferential statistics is to try to deduce the value of population parameters from samples. Every sample gives us a "best guess" or point estimate to these values. These two sections will introduce some general facts about point estimation and methods of point estimation, such as the method of moments.

Learning Outcomes

  • Describe the idea of Random Sampling
  • Compare a Statistic and a Parameter
  • Explain the concept of a Sampling distribution
  • State the Central Limit Theorem
  • Describe the sampling distributions of the sample mean and proportion
  • Define the sampling distribution of S^2
  • Describe the t and F Distributions

Overview

Module 5 is the first of two modules where we study statistical inference.  The notion of statistical inference is the estimation of parameters based on a sample while at the same time giving a precise notion of error in our estimates based on the sampling distributions of our statistics.  This module will introduce the notion of a confidence interval. In a confidence interval we give a range of values for a population parameter.  The middle of this interval consists of the point estimate based on our sample.  To this point estimate we give width to the confidence interval by adding and subtracting a certain amount of error that depends on the sampling distribution of the statistic. We will introduce prediction intervals and give precise equations for confidence intervals of population mean, variance, and standard deviation.  In addition to looking at inference based on one sample we will introduce several examples that involve two samples from different populations.

Learning Outcomes

  • Define Statistical Inference
  • Define a Confidence Interval
  • Calculate the estimate of a sample mean from a single sample
  • Describe the Standard Error of a Point Estimate
  • Describe a Prediction Interval
  • Produce an estimate for the difference between the means from two samples
  • Compute the estimate of a sample proportion from a single sample
  • Produce an estimate for the difference between the sample proportions from two samples

Overview

This module covers Sections 8.1-8.5 and Sections 9.3-9.5 of course text. Sections 8.1-8.5 introduce hypothesis tests on a single sample. Section 8.1 is of paramount importance for learning the underlying terms and concepts of statistical hypotheses and the test procedure. Sections 8.2 and 8.3 introduce the one sample Z and T tests for population mean. Then, hypothesis tests for population proportion are introduced. Sections 9.3-9.5 introduce two-sample hypothesis tests. Two sample hypothesis tests allow us to test parameters between two distributions. For example, we can test whether the average salary is the same at two different companies, or, whether average time to failure for a component is the same for two different manufacturing lines.

Learning Outcomes

  • Define a Statistical Hypothesis
  • Define a Statistical Hypothesis Test
  • Explain the concept of a p-value for making decisions in hypothesis testing
  • Describe and conduct a hypothesis test for a single mean
  • Describe and conduct a hypothesis test for the difference between two means
  • Illustrate sample size calculations in hypothesis testing
  • Identify and conduct a hypothesis test for a single proportion
  • Identify and conduct a hypothesis test for the difference between two proportions
  • Assess the validity of claims of the values population means and proportions

In Module 2 we will introduce random variables, distributions, and expectations. Random variables should be considered as a function on the sample space of an experiment. Recall that a sample space is the set of all outcomes to an experiment, so a random variable assigns a number to each outcome. We say this variable is "random" because the numerical output depends on the outcome of a random experiment. For example, if our experiment was "select one person from Company A" then X=salary of person would be a random variable for this experiment. The distribution of a random variable summarizes the values a random variable can take and the probability it takes that value. Finally, expectations generalize the idea of "average" to random variables.

In Module 3 we will introduce several different examples of important discrete and continuous random variables. These include the binomial, multinomial, and hypergeometric distributions, the negative binomial and geometric distribution, the Poisson distribution, the normal distribution, the gamma distribution, the exponential distribution, and the chi-squared distribution. All of these distributions have important applications to statistical testing (which we will cover later) or physical applications, many of which appear in engineering.

In Module 4 we will start to connect our developments in probability theorem during modules 2 & 3 with inferential statistics. In general we are going to try to infer parameters of distributions using a finite list of samples. This is a major course theme. A parameter describes a population in it's entirety, but very often we do not know what it is. Moreover, we have no way of calculating it exactly. The best we can do is sample a finite number of observations from the population and estimate. We will talk about random sampling, estimating parameters, the central limit theorem, sampling distributions, and the sampling distributions of some of the parameters that we will be interested in studying!

In Module 5 we will introduce the notion of a confidence interval. A confidence interval gives a range of possible values for a population parameter based on an observed sample. It consists of making a point estimate, which we learned about in this module, and making that the center (or best guess) for our confidence interval. Then we add and subtract an error value that is based on a level of uncertainty and the sampling distribution. We will also introduce to the analogous idea for a two-sample procedure from two different populations where we would like to compare parameters.

Module 6 is the last module of our course! In this module, we will introduce the notion of hypothesis testing. In a hypothesis test we have very specific statistical hypotheses which are claims about population parameters. We then observe a sample. After taking a point estimate the parameter we are testing, we make a specific measure of error between the hypothesized value and the observed estimate. The crux of the hypothesis test is the technique used to quantify how much error is "unusual" which leads up to reject our hypothesis and how much error is not unusual in which case we fail to reject our hypothesis. We will develop hypothesis tests for mean and proportion and we will also develop "two samples" versions which allow us to compare parameters of different distributions.

Community of Learners

Complete the readings and activities listed below.  These activities are intended to help you engage with the content of the course AND get acquainted with other members taking this course. 

1. Ask Your Professor Discussion Board

The Ask Your Professor discussion board is for asking questions about the course. By asking your questions there you enable the whole class to benefit from your questions. Since everyone can view your question, this is not for personal and private questions. Please email all private and personal questions directly to me.

  1. Required - Subscribe the the Ask Your Professor discussion board
  2. Optional - Create a thread to ask a question. Do you have course-related questions the Start Here Study assignments or the syllabus, for example, that you want to ask now?

Please use this forum throughout the course to ask me questions.  As a student, if you know the answer, feel free to jump in and help out your fellow classmate(s).

2. Personal Introductions

Go to the discussion board, click on the Student Lounge, and write an introduction that will let the others in the course get to know you. Be sure to include your major, where you live (general - like I live in Cincinnati), and a "fun fact" about you.

The Student Lounge is a student-led discussion board for asking your classmates questions, particularly during the hours that your instructor is unavailable. This discussion board will be available to you for the duration of the semester.  I highly recommend you subscribe to this forum.   Subscribing to this forum will enable you to stay in the loop automatically. You will receive an email every time someone posts to the forum. To Subscribe,  click on the Subscribe button under the discussion post. 

3. Private Journal Entry - What I Need to Know About You

You will be asked to complete private journal entries every module this semester.

For this journal, I ask that you share anything that you think is important for me to know as we begin this class. Remember, the journals are private so the only two people who see your entries are you and myself.  List anything that you feel I need to know as it has the potential to have an impact on your success in this course. 

Click on the Journal: What you need to know about me to start.

Welcome to STAT 2037!

This course will consist of an introduction to probability and statistics using a calculus-based approach. More specifically we will introduce basic probability theory, random variables, discrete and continuous random variables, a wide variety of common types of distributions, an inferential statistics techniques.  This course will assume that you are already familiar with basic differential and integral calculus. Our motivation will be toward applying these ideas to engineering problems.

Please complete the learning activities below, which will introduce you to the course and give you an idea of the tools needed to learn in an online environment. If you find that an online class is not for you, please let me know as soon as possible.

I look forward to getting to meet you all and seeing what the semester brings!

For this assignment you will send an email to your course instructor using the Inbox in the left Canvas navigation menu. For more information on how to send an email through Canvas, please read the instruction on How to Use Inbox as a Student. 

What to include in the email:

When you send an email through Canvas your course title and section will automatically appear as part of the email subject. For this email, in addition to the course title and section, please add My Preparedness for Learning Math Online at the end of the subject of your email. This will enable your facilitator to better identify and locate your email. Please use formal format for this email, and all other email, including a salutation, body, closing, and signature. For more information regarding formal email format, please read How to Write a Formal Email.

 In the message of the email please include the following:

  1. A statement that you have read and understood the syllabus and course calendar. 
  2. A statement that you have read and will follow the netiquette information.
  3. A concise reflective summary of your preparedness for this course, including your plan of action for success, based on the results of the Distance Learning Quiz and information in the Online Survival Guide.
  4. Best telephone number to contact you, the city you live, and your time zone.
  5. If applicable, any special circumstances that you can foresee this semester (planned travel, family situations, etc.).

That is it for our course introducing probability and inferential statistics! It has been a challenging course! Let us recap some of the things we learned:

  1. Probability & counting strategies.
  2. Random variables and distributions.
  3. Important classes of random variables.
  4. Sampling statistics and distributions.
  5. Confidence intervals
  6. Hypothesis testing

Each homework question can be repeatedly attempted. Homework is a learning experience- do not be discouraged if you get a problem wrong on the first try! You should think of homework as the combined time investment of homework and lecture in a face-to-face course.

Once you have completed the set, new attempts that you make at the assignment will generate "new" problems to test your skills. You should revisit the assignment as necessary to test yourself. What I Need to Know About You 

Writing in your journal is a weekly assignment that counts for significant points in this class.

It is important to reflect and explain your understanding of the course content in your own words.

The journal is also a place for you to have a private conversation with me, your instructor.  

For this journal entry, please share anything that you believe is important for me to know as we begin this journey together. Include anything that you believe has the potential to impact your success in this course. 

Remember, the journals are private.
